title: How to Make an Ice Bath for Cooking

methods.name: Shocking Food with an Ice Bath

steps.headline: Fill a bowl half full of ice.
steps.description: Set a large bowl next to your stove and pour in enough ice cubes to fill the bowl halfway. Although you can use any type of bowl, thin metal bowls will cool the food faster than glass or ceramic. You can use crushed ice, but it will melt faster than ice cubes.

steps.headline: Pour in enough cold water to fill 3/4 of the bowl.
steps.description: It's important to use cold water so you don't begin melting the ice cubes in the bowl. Fill the bowl until it's 3/4 full to prevent it from overflowing when you add the food that you want to chill. Your ice bath is now ready to use for cooling food quickly.

steps.headline: Blanch your food for 2 to 5 minutes.
steps.description:
Boil about 1 pound (450 g) of chopped vegetables until they turn bright in color. Since the texture and density of vegetables varies, follow a blanching guideline. In general, boil:

Green beans or broccoli florets for 3 minutes
Diced carrots or pepper strips for 2 minutes

Cauliflower florets for 2 minutes

steps.headline: Use a slotted spoon to transfer the food to the ice bath.
steps.description: Once the vegetables are as crisp as you like, scoop up the vegetables with a slotted spoon and place them directly into the ice bath. Work quickly so the ice water stops the vegetables from cooking further. Ensure that the vegetables are completely submerged in the ice water.

steps.headline: Chill the food in the ice bath until it's completely cold.
steps.description: Plan on leaving the food in the ice water for about as long as you boiled the food. For example, if you boiled peas for 1 minute, chill them for 1 minute. Then, use a slotted spoon to remove the blanched vegetables from the ice bath.Tip: If you'd like to quickly cool a liquid, such as a sauce or custard base for ice cream, pour it into a metal bowl. Set the bowl into the ice bath and leave it until the liquid is cold.

methods.name: Cooling Large Batches of Food Safely

steps.headline: Fill a sink or large container half full of ice.
steps.description: Clean a sink or large container that's designated for food. Then, pour in enough ice to come halfway up the side of the sink or container. Use ice cubes instead of crushed ice since the cubes won't melt as quickly. Metal containers cool food faster than plastic storage containers.

steps.headline: Place a container with the hot food into the ice.
steps.description: Put the hot food that you want to cool into a metal container or bowl. Then, nestle the container directly in the ice. Don't worry if the heat of the food melts some of the ice. To cool the food even faster, put it in a large, shallow container instead of a small deep one.

steps.headline: Add ice until it's level with the top of the food container.
steps.description: Pour more ice into the sink or ice bath. Keep adding ice until it surrounds the food container and is level with the top.

steps.headline: Stir the food every 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Stirring redistributes the heat so the ice cools the food evenly. You may need to add more ice as the food chills to keep it level with the food in the storage container. If you're chilling food in a container, you can drain some of the melted water to prevent it from spilling over the sides.

steps.headline: Monitor the temperature to ensure that the food cools safely.
steps.description: To prevent bacterial growth, the food needs to cool to 40 °F (4 °C) within 6 hours of being placed in the ice bath. Check the temperature every 2 hours, using a clean instant-read thermometer.Did You Know? Bacteria grows rapidly between 41 and 135 °F (5 and 57 °C), which is why this is called the temperature danger zone. The food should fall to 70 °F (21 °C) within the first 2 hours of chilling in the ice bath. If it hasn't cooled to 70 °F (21 °C), you'll need to reheat the food before chilling it again.

steps.headline: Transfer the food to the refrigerator once it reaches 40 °F (4 °C).
steps.description: As soon as the temperature of the food drops to 40 °F (4 °C) when you check it with the thermometer, move it to the refrigerator. Store the food in the fridge until you're ready to use it. Remember to label the food and include the date so you know when to use it by. For example, write "tomato soup, 12/20."
